history.content:
If you are worried about declaring, I would definitely not recommend this schedule. While I do not know about Math 100, both CS 61B and EE 16B (with EE 16B being the highest workload lower-division course in EECS) are high workload classes, and if taken together, I would recommend only adding a light breadth. And depending on how worried you are about declaring (ex. poor performance in CS 61A), I would leave out EE 16B. CS 61B is a fundamental CS course, so having additional time to truly understand the concepts will help a lot more in the long run than stacking classes to perhaps declare or graduate early.

I am a CS Peer Advisor, so feel free to stop by in front of HP Auditorium M/W 2-4 PM if you want to chat more about this!

children.subject: I took basically that schedule last spring (61B + 16B + 54 + R1A) and it was overall doable, but I didn't have that much time to focus on 61B and I never really internalized data structures, and I wish I had. I'm in Math 110 now and it's easier than 61B or 16B in my opinion - keep in mind math upper divs are literally zero work besides the problem sets unlike engineering/CS classes (and I've taken EE 16AB + Math 54 so it's my third/fourth run through linear algebra, so my opinion on it may be biased) - but if you're worried about declaring I'd forego 16B to be able to focus on getting the most out of 61B and 110, they're both awesome classes that you really should try to get the most out of (16B is too, but it sounds like you can afford to push it back).

I took 61B and EE16A, combined with a decal + heavy reading class. Would definitely discourage this if you are trying to declare. 61B itself with Hilfinger will be very time consuming. Whenever the projects come, you will really not have time to invest in your other classes. EE16B is a hard class if EE is not obvious to you. It also covers a lot of material in a small amount of time and overall draws from many parts of EE that are usually taught in different courses in other schools. I would heavily discourage you from taking those two plus Math 110 together, unless you really understood everything from the EE part of EE16A and you feel that you linear algebra foundations are good enough to not invest a lot of time on Math 110

I am a sophomore who took only 61a Freshman year. I repent taking EE16A alongside 61B and EE16B (currently) with CS 70 bc I ended up prioritizing my CS classes over my EECS classes, but still had to put time into EE, so I have been juggling the whole thing this semester and the past one. You have plenty of time to get your reqs done. Really avoid 16B with 61B; both consume too much time and are a terrible combination together. Take Math 53 (semi-mandatory if you want to pursue the ML track) with 61B. Take R1B if you haven't taken it yet. Take a breadth. Take a course for fun. It is not worth jeopardizing declaring just to blew up reqs out of the way fast.

Since the consensus seems to be to not do ee16b with 61b if we are worried about declaring, when should I hold off ee16b until? I am a rising sophomore who has only done 61a and 16a and would do 61b in the fall and cs70 in the spring, but then I have to push off 16b (and possibly 61c) to some future time. When should that future time be? I am running out of breadths and do not know what other classes to take next year if I only do one of the 3.3 classes per semester next year.

history.content:
Is this course load doable for next fall semester? Would I have enough time to focus on 61b to make sure I can declare? 

Thanks!
history.subject: CS61B + EE16B + Math 110 + Breadth
